Incident.Summary: DECEASED PERSON AT 1 WEST PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE IN WALKERSVILLE, MD.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: **CAR B-66/IN-CAR CAMERA NOT AVIALABLE/BODY-WORN CAMERA AVAILABLE** ASSISTING: CPL CONKLIN #5549, IN-CAR CAMERA NOT AVIALABLE/BODY-WORN CAMERA AVAILABLE ATTACHMENTS: MVA Printouts MSP Form 89B Death Investigation Report Photographs of the scene VICTIM: Andrew Nathan Stull (DOB 03/26/1979) ***DECEASED*** 1 West Pennsylvania Avenue Walkersville, Maryland 21793 WITNESS(ES)/COMPLAINANT(S): Timothy Dylan Stull (DOB 10/10/1976) 1 West Pennsylvania Avenue Walkersville, Maryland 21793 Timothy is the brother of the deceased. Timothy advised Andrew has prior health conditions, a majority of them stemming from drug use. Timothy advised Andrew also had a history of alcohol abuse. Timothy advised Andrews drug use included heroin, fentanyl, cocaine, and prescription pills. Timothy advised had a history of mobility issues, and problems with circulation in his legs and feet. Timothy advised he last saw Andrew alive at his residence at approximately 1100-1200 hours, on 03/13/2023. Timothy advised his mother, Diane Stull, heard Andrew in the residence alive, on the night of 03/13/2023, at approximately 2100 hours. Timothy advised on todays date, 03/14/2023, he arrived at the residence to take Andrew to a drug rehabilitation appointment scheduled for 1030 hours. Timothy advised at approximately 0810 hours (Approximately 3 hours prior to the 911 call), he observed Andrew laying on his left side on the couch, located in the living room of the residence, covered in blankets. Timothy advised as soon as he saw Andrew, he could tell Andrew was clearly deceased. Timothy advised once he found Andrew, he made contact with his mother, Diane Stull, who was at the residence, in her bedroom upstairs, and informed her of Andrews death. Timothy advised he also made contact with Andrews son, Dylan Stull, and informed him of the death. It should be noted, Timothy advised he waited approximately 3 hours before he called 911 to report the death. It should be noted, Andrew was not currently prescribed any medications. Timothy advised Andrew did not have a primary care physician, and refused to go see a Doctor. Timothy also advised Andrew was previously hospitalized on 03/09/2023 or 03/10/2023, for a severe alcohol overdose. Timothy advised Andrews BAC was listed at a .39 at Frederick Health Hospital the day he was hospitalized. SCENE PROCESSING: At 1058 hours, Cpl. Conklin #5549 and I were dispatched. At 1101 hours, Cpl. Conklin and I arrived on scene. At 1101 hours, EMS personnel arrived on scene. At 1102 hours, EMS personnel pronounced the subject deceased. Cpl. Conklin and I observed the deceased, identified as Andrew Stull, located in the downstairs living room, laying on left side on the couch. The room temperature was approximately 65- 70 degrees. Andrew was wearing a white underwear, and a light green tee shirt. Andrew had no pulse, was cold to the touch, lividity was present in his face, both arms, and both legs. Rigor mortis was clearly present. There were no signs of trauma on Andrews person.It should be noted, a blue powdery substance was located on the mantle in the living room, with a credit card containing the blue powder in close proximity. Photographs of the scene were taken, and the photographs were uploaded to Veripic per agency policy. At 1131 hours, the OCME Office was contacted, and responded to the scene. At 1152 hours, OCME J. Droneburg responded to the scene. Verbal statements gathered by family members on scene. NARRATIVE: On 03/14/2023, at 1058 hours, I (TFC Blumenauer #6357) of the Maryland State Police was on duty when I was dispatched to 1 West Pennsylvania Avenue in Walkersville, Frederick County, Maryland for the report of a cardiac arrest and possible death investigation. At 1101 hours, Cpl. Conklin #5549 and I responded to the scene. At approximately 1101 hours, EMS Personnel also responded to the scene. (EMS Run #F23007680, Ambulance 248). When EMS personnel first arrived on scene, the patient, identified as Andrew Nathan Stull (DOB 03/26/1979), was not responsive or breathing. It should be noted, an obvious death was observed. Andrew was cold to the touch, and rigor mortis was present. Lividity was also present in the face, both arms, and both legs of the deceased. Lifesaving procedures were not conducted due to the obvious death. At 1102 hours, Andrew Stull was pronounced deceased by Firefighter/EMT K. Fields of the Frederick County DFRS (Engine 248). While on scene, I made contact with the victims brother, identified as Timothy Dylan Stull (DOB 10/10/1976), by his Maryland drivers license. Verbal statements gathered on scene, see above. It should be noted, Andrew Stull did not have a primary care physician. At approximately 1125 hours, Sgt. T. Hill #1652 (Frederick Barrack Duty Officer), and Cpl. Conklin #5549 contacted the Office of the Medical Examiner (OCME). At 1131 hours, it was determined that the OCME Office would be responding to the scene. At 1152 hours, John Droneburg of the OCME responded to the scene. MSP Criminal Enforcement Division (CED) was also contacted, and advised they would not be responding to the scene. The cause of death was deemed undetermined at this time. There were no signs of foul play, or suspicious circumstances related to the death. There werealso no signs of trauma to the victim. At 1252 hours, Meek Mortuary Transport responded to the scene and transported Jameson to the OCME Office in Baltimore. MSP Form 89b Death Investigation Report completed and added to the attachments section of this report. All of these events occurred in Frederick County, Maryland. CASE STATUS: Case open pending results of the OCME autopsy.

NARRATIVE: On 05/23/2023, at 1619 hours, I received the Autopsy report for this case by email from Tiffinney Green, Records Office for the OCME. Upon review of the autopsy report, I noted several findings. The OCME case number was #23-03410. The autopsy was conducted on 03/15/2023, at 0900 hours, and was performed by Theodore M. King, (M.D., Assistant Medical Examiner). It should be noted the cause of death for Stull was noted as alcohol and fentanyl intoxication, and the death was ruled as could not be determined. It should be noted the toxicology report was positive for alcohol with a range of .31-.41 BAC. Toxicology report also showed fentanyl was also present. A copy of the OCME Autopsy report was added to the attachments section of this report. CASE STATUS: Case closed.
